awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Hydrologic Open Cooling System (HOCS) for low-energy refrigeration
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a technology enabling low-energy, resilient cooling that is capable of mitigating the environmental impacts and high costs of conventional refrigeration. There is a critical need for sustainable cooling solutions that provide an alternative to hydrofluorocarbon-based refrigerants that rely on carbon dioxide (CO2)-emitting systems. This project seeks to develop a Hydrologic Open Cooling System (HOCS) that can maintain cooling chambers at 1.5-5°C utilizing 10% or less of the electrical power of conventional systems. This project unlocks environmental heat as an energy reservoir and offsets significant energy costs of conventional cooling systems. The technology can support highly efficient refrigeration at a fraction of the operational cost and electrical demand of traditional systems. Adoption of this cooling technology by small- to mid-size supermarkets would enable significant cost savings for electricity. On a broader scale, widespread implementation of this innovation across a variety of refrigeration applications would reduce greenhouse gas emissions and energy consumption, meeting the need for sustainable technologies to support food and energy security while upholding climate goals.

This SBIR Phase I project develops a renewable, closed container cooling system incorporating a rechargeable vacuum insulation and a novel two-stage heat pump. This project involves 1) developing a rechargeable vacuum insulation technology that does not use vacuum pumps; 2) creating a modified dewar connected to a fully renewable cooling system enabling cooled inner chambers; and 3) evaluating the ability to use environmental heat to restore the solutions that power the cooling system allowing their reuse. The novel heat pump technology is based on two asynchronous stages: the first utilizes concentration gradients as a driving mechanism enabling thermal transfer, while the second uses environmental heat to re-concentrate saline solutions after dilution during stage one. Together, these two stages enable cooling of a closed container. The project will examine system configurations able to generate large thermal gradients, enabling maintenance of 1.5-5°C temperatures within the dewar. Advantages of this system include 1) the system’s ability to cool continues in the absence of electricity making it resilient to power outages from itinerant weather, wildfires, and earthquakes; 2) lossless storage of cooling capacity; and 3) significantly reducing the greenhouse gas footprint compared to conventional refrigeration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The hydrologic system governs how water moves around the planet, drives much of weather, and provides water needed to power hydroelectric systems. It is powered, at the core, by dinural thermal variations which, in turn, adjust how water evaporates into and condenses out of air. This constant changing of how the air is humidified provides an energy-acquisition opportunity that has heretofore remained unused. This project is aimed at developing a practical cooling system capable of using this humidification variation as a viable energy source.
 
The evaporation of water from seawater to produce sea salt is an area where the relative humidity and the energy in the air interact to enable real, useful work to be derived from spontaneous work of the environment on seawater. During the daily variability of humidity, significant lengths of time exist during which the relative humidity is below the vapor pressure of the salt water, even at saturation. In this case, the heat energy in the air drives evaporation of the water, producing salt. In this process the sea water’s entropy is reduced. Having a low entropy solution is an opportunity that until now hasn’t been properly exploited.
 
Our initial approach to using this process was to use the efficient evaporation of water from varied saline solutions to produce concentrated saline solutions that could be used to directly drive an entrochemical cooling system. An entrochemical cooling system uses thermal gradients produced between two liquid pools of different osmolarity when connected by a wet vacuum to produce cooling. During the project, however, a technological breakthrough occurred which encouraged us to adjust the goals of the project to reflect a more straightforward path to market and cooling. Our solution to developing a hydrologic open cooling system now envisions using off-the-shelf sorption-based cooling technology together with our novel technology which uses environmental heat to provide the high concentration sorbents that drive the cooling.
 
The project led to three major accomplishments. The first is the development of a technology that enables the spontaneous use of low concentration salt solutions to regenerate, or remove the water from, higher concentration salt solutions. Like membrane-enabled osmosis, this involves moving water between different salt solutions with different concentrations. Unlike osmosis, the novel system spontaneously moves water from the more concentrated solution to a less concentrated solution; no additional energy is required outside of that required to prime the apparatus and the environmental enthalpy that is passively absorbed by the system during operation. This system was experimentally validated with a series of experiments including a set that exhibited the first spontaneous self-regeneration of a salt solution. That self regeneration experiment involved loading a 7M CaCl2 solution into the novel apparatus along with a quantity of tap water and later recovering the remaining tap water concentrate, a quantity of 4M CaCl2 solution and a quantity of 9.7 M CaCl2 solution.
 
The second major accomplishment is the development of an outdoor regenerator that regenerates low concentration saline solutions via simple evaporation. The system also passively recovers the heat of vaporization lost due to the evaporation of the water from the solution, enhancing its performance. During the study this outdoor regenerator was successfully used to regenerate a variety of saline solutions and obtain osmolarities of up to 15. In some cases the evaporation yielded crystals which could be collected and used to make new solutions. The reconcentrated salt solutions were repeatedly used over an extended four-month period. The regenerator exhibited a maximum evaporative wattage of 2800W while using only 96W of driving energy, a capability that demonstrates that the majority of the energy required to effect the evaporation came directly from the air. The new regenerator design exhibited a 60% improvement in capacity compared to simple swamp cooler-type regenerators.
 
The third accomplishment is the generation of data that demonstrates that evaporation-based regeneration can concentrate salt solutions which can then be used to spontaneously concentrate more highly concentrated salt solutions within the ring regenerator that are useful for industrial application. This is called closing the energy loop. From an energy perspective, it means that energy is initially expended by the environment on a low concentration solution, reducing its entropy. Then this solution spontaneously receives the water from a higher concentration solution. That second, now dry, more concentrated solution is then ready for use in driving any number of sorption-based processes. The energy to drive these steps is the energy required to do the initial evaporation, and that comes from the heat in the air.
 
This work establishes a technology and process for practically accessing environmental heat and using it to enable work. The solution, which significantly differs from the original approach, is applicable to many areas including cooling, dehumidification, and distillation. Work on scaling this technology is the logical next step.

Last Modified: 07/19/2024
Modified by: Sanza Kazadi
